Award.AwardTitle: Developing a Seafloor Sediment Multicorer With a Real-time Camera System for US Oceanographic Multidisciplinary Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution proposes to take advantage of an off-the-shelf, commonly used Multicorer system developed by Ocean Instruments, Inc. (Model MC800) that is presently operated by at least six UNOLS operating institutions. This system would be integrated with WHOI-MISO deep-sea cameras, strobes, data transmission electronics, and basic water sampling and CTD capabilities to provide a more capable and comprehensive Multicorer capability for routine use on UNOLS vessels.

The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The motivation for the development of this instrument was to develop a real-time, camera-operated multicorer system tto be used in a variety of sedimentary settings where spatially restricted habitats occur. Examples of these habitats include hydrocarbon seeps, mud volcanoes, sediment-covered hydrothermal vents such as Guaymas Basin, the zone where the chemocline impinges the seafloor in silled basins such as the Cariaco Basin, Black Sea, Deep Hypersaline Anoxic Basins (DHABs) and fjords such as Saanich Inlet.

The key objectives of this project were successfully carried out during the test cruise in Oct. 2013 onboard the Scripps ship RV Melville. We demonstrated the viability of routine imaging via WHOI-MISO equipment on the MC-800 multicorer for future science programs that require use of this type sampling equipment in order to recover welllocated and bottom-characterized samples.

The equipment used During the Engineering Test Cruise – MV1214: Two (2) MC-800 multicorers were prepared for deployment using RV Melville’s 0.680” coaxial conducting cable and the 0.322” CTD cable. Each corer was rigged with 8 sampling tubes. Aluminum and fiberglass mounting brackets were fabricated for easy installation of all equipment to the standard MC-800 multicorer frame.

Results from the test cruise:
17 multicorer deployments were carried out; 15 were successful. On one deployment the corers did not trigger due to operator error, and the last station was at very shallow depth and the corer did not penetrate the firmly-compacted, sandy sediments. We used two MC-800 multicorers (one from WHOI – newly purchased as part of this grant and placed into the WHOI-SSSG instrument pool so it can be accessed by all UNOLS users - and one from SIO). Both the 0.680" coax wire deployed off Melville's stern and the 0.322" CTD conducting cable deployed off the starboard A-frame were utilized in carrying out coring operations.

Two complete multicorer systems were operational during the cruise with the MISO imaging and CTD systems installed so we could easily switch back and forth between the two conducting cables. Both systems had the same configuration with a 16 megapixel OIS digital camera, 600 watt/sec 2-head strobe system, SBE25 CTD w/dissolved O2 sensor and downlooking
altimeter, and one 5 liter Niskin bottle. Photographs of the seafloor were transmitted up each of the conducting wires using the WHOI-MISO 'DataLink' electronics which permitted us to image in real time the seafloor during multicorer operations. The images were transmitted via the DataLink up each cable and displayed in the lab where we were controlling the winch so we could hover 2-5 m above the seafloor and select the sample sites. Images were acquired every 10 seconds. This system allowed us to position the multicorer within 1 m from the seafloor and carefully control bottom impact - which was especially important while sampling the bacterial mats in the Santa Barbara Basin, which can be difficult to sample in terms of over penetration and minimizing disturbance to the sediments and water/sediment interface.

It is now planned to write a short Eos article on the results from our multicorer w/camera & CTD development effort and test cruise, in order to implementing routine science operations with the multicorer with camera & CTD system via the MISO Facility. We also plan to contact PIs who have used UNOLS multicorer systems in the past 5 years to inform them of this new capability, and add the multicorer system information to MISO website: http://www.whoi.edu/page.do?pid=13575
